content.description:
Bus Station with “Colored Waiting Room” Sign, Durham, North Carolina, 1940

The black-and-white photograph shows a few Black people waiting to board a bus at a bus station.

In the left foreground, a man stands facing rightward and mostly away from the camera. Above him are signs reading “Colored Waiting Room” and “Private Property, No Parking, Driving Through or Turning Around.”

There are a few additional people in the background.

In the right foreground is a parked bus with several people onboard, “Carolina Coach Company 45” written on the side, and luggage stowed on top.

A second bus is shown parked in the background
Photo by: Universal History Archive/Universal Images Group via Getty Images
content.question: Which of the following most directly ended widespread segregation in the South?

choices.label: The landmark piece of federal legislation that outlawed discriminatory practices in voting
Peaceful sit-ins like those at lunch counters in the South in the 1960s
Nonviolent marches such as the March on Washington in 1963
The federal act that prohibited discrimination on the basis of race, color, and religion

content.answer: The federal act that prohibited discrimination on the basis of race, color, and religion
